Entries.default: "Hey, Watcher, I need to, uh, be straight with you about something."
"I've been here before."
"Seems like you did a lot more than visit."
[Say nothing.]
"Yeah, you got me there. You're too perceptive, you know that? It's almost creepy."
"This place... it's not just an island full of crazy druids and giant boars. It's a competition."
"There's an actual arena in the middle, but that's just where people congregate. "The entire island is a trial."
"One that I fought in."
"How long ago did you fight here?"
"Did you win the fights?"
"Can you give me any insight into what's to come?"
"Few years."
"Did you fight alone?"
"Hah! You flatter me. Nah, I may be tough, but I'm not that tough."
"I had a crew. A group. Packs they call them here. Something almost like a family."
"We worked well together, but... You know how it is. Nothing good stays good forever."
"When I left, we went our separate ways."
"Did you have a falling out?"
"Something like that."
"See, we were doing pretty well in the contests. Not just winning, but winning handily. Dominating."

"But something wasn't right. I just couldn't shake this feeling we were being played. Being used. And I didn't know what for."

He hesitates.

"So, when I quit, my crew got mad. 'How can you give up now? We're nearly there!' That kind of stuff.

"But I had to trust my gut. Couldn't go dying and leave my pa alone, could I?"

"I'm past the age of chasing glory, Watcher. Let me make a little coin, settle down somewhere with a view... Shit, maybe I go back home to the Pearl Coast.

"Haven't been there in an age."
"Do you miss it, your home?" Rekke butts in, an eager look about him.
"Well, yeah. Probably not like you miss yours, on account of how I can probably go back..."
"But it is hard. To return."
"Harder even than leaving. Yeah."
"Why? Did something happen?"
[Motion for him to go on.]
"No, nothing. And that's just the thing. Folks were... nice to us."
"Too nice, right? Kind of nice that makes you wonder what a person's looking to get from you?"
"When you caught me in Neketaka, I was at the tail end of a long rest."
"That kind of life - wake up, fight, sleep, every day for weeks - it takes a lot out of a person."
"Maybe it took more out of me than I thought."
"But it's addictive, too. Living like that."
"Yeah, and you know that better than most, don't you?"

"You don't just walk away from that life. Something bigger always needs to take its place."

Maia looks like she wants to say more, but stops herself.
"Aye, lass. Bigger boats, bigger booty. Bigger bottles of brew." He bumps his eyebrows at Maia.
"What's on your mind?"
"Tell me about the crew you ran with."
"What's the story behind your tattoos?"
"Uh huh, sure. So, what gang did you run with?"
"Ah, you don't want to hear about that. It's ancient history at this point." He shifts his weight from foot to foot, not quite meeting your eye.
"I'm genuinely curious. You seem too laid-back to be a leader."
"Another time, then."
"I want to know more about you."
"Yeah... thanks." He breathes a sigh of relief, but frowns.
"Aw Hel, you'll make a man blush."
"Ouch, Watcher!" He laughs, a deep rumble that shakes his whole body.
"Well, there was Saelis, an old elf from Aedyr. Could do wild stuff with a bow - back flips, trick shots. Stuff you'd only see at a traveling show."
"Well, there was Saelis, an old elf from Aedyr. Could do wild stuff with a bow - back flips, trick shots. Stuff you'd only see at a traveling show."
"Then there was my sister."
"Heh. Youthful folly. Nothing more to it than that."
"Can't say I know what'll happen 'til it's happening, but I'll tell you what I can when I can." He shrugs, his large hands turned palm up.
He shrugs. "I'm standing here. Wait - I'm not dead, am I?"
"There's no surrender in the arena. You lose, you die. Keeps it simple."
"You always take us to the nicest places, Watcher."
"Hey now, least it's warm this time. It's nice not having to worry about anything turning blue and falling off."
"Every story ends in death, friend Konstanten."
"Go on."
"Family drama? I'll pass."
"Probably wise." He grimaces.
"She thought those fights were gonna fix everything short of bringing our ma back from the grave."
"We could've put our pa up in a nice place, maybe even gotten him a valet or a steward. Someone to help him hunt and farm so he could focus on tending his bees."
"Didn't work out like that, though, and she wouldn't forgive me for it. Haven't seen her since."
"Ac, it is much the same in the Republics. Many wear a smile as a mask."
"Anything more than that'd just be idle speculation, and that's not really my thing."
"A scalp tattoo isn't something you do on a whim."
"Wasn't a gang. Not really." He mutters something under his breath, though you can't quite make out what.
"It was more like a... religious organization?"
"The tattoos look good on you."
"Oh, okay."

"Heh, thanks. Can't say I pay much attention to the latest trends - not too fond of the Vailian passion for puffy sleeves, for one thing - but I still make an effort to look sharp.

"For the ladies." He winks.
"Well hey, thanks." He grins and claps you on the shoulder.
"You got a way with compliments, Watcher. Keep 'em coming." He winks.
"Sure it is. You never been young and stupid? Kids'll do all sorts of dumb shit to stave off boredom."
"Is that a euphemism for 'cult?'"
[Scoff.] "Don't tell me you were a priest."
"That makes it sound a lot more exciting than what it was - which was guarding a temple of Magran from crazed Eothasians, mostly."
"The other guards were a rowdy bunch. Liked to egg each other on to acts of foolishness."
"Sounds like fun."
"That doesn't seem like something you'd approve of."
"How juvenile."
"It was, for a while. Better than kicking my heels on my pa's farm, anyway."
[Motion for him to go on.]
"Lots of the guards had tattoos. Getting them meant you were really one of the group."

"Was my pa ever pissed!

"Used to be kind of embarrassed by 'em, to tell the truth. Looking back now, though, I'm glad I marked that time in my life."
"It's important to remember where you've come from. What you've done."
"Were you a priest?"
"I'm sick to death of the gods. Let's talk about something else."
"Like get their faces all cut up." He glances at Rekke, and his mouth twists into a sly smile.
"Just because your Aedyran is not my first language does not mean I cannot hear you, Konstanten!"
"I was a guard at a temple of Magran. I've never been much for organized religion, truth be told, but the coin was all right."
"Gods, no. Nothing so grand."
"Oh, I know." He winks.
"Anyway, I was a member of a, uh, religious organization for a time. Tattoos were part of the deal."
"Thought I was done with all that. But here I am, 'bout to make the same bad choices."
"Not sure how my letters are gonna find her now that we spend so much time on the move." His expression softens and his eyes take on a distant, unfocused look. He frowns and turns away.
"Your father keeps bees?"
"Used to. Not sure if he does anymore."
"Had a bitterly cold winter out where he lives not too many years ago."

"He ended up losing a few queens to the cold.

"That was a tough year."
"We should get going."
"Yeah, not a safe place to be standing around."
He takes a deep breath and starts toward the forest's edge, dividing the foliage with the easy confidence of a ship parting the sea.
[Leave] "Let's talk later."
"Can't help but worry about what Eothas is up to after that Saint's War business. Nothing good comes from the gods meddlin' in kith affairs."
"She's... She's, uh... Huh." He trails off, looking a little at a loss for words.
"I'll be here if you need me."
"Later, then."
"Sure thing."

"It's just me, her, and pa, after all. Family has to stick together."

He sighs, and his shoulder slump forward.
"Do you want to talk about your sister?"
"What're you, my priest? Don't need to talk about anything." He crosses his arms and kicks idly at the ground.
"I could be, if you wanted me to be."
"Come on. What's her name?"
"Do you miss her?"
"My soul's always pulled toward Magran. Not sure another god would have anything to do with it."
"Can't say I'm much for the faith at the moment. If that changes, you'll be the first to know." He smiles.
"Roza, and my pa's Dorin, before you ask. Ma was Denisa, and I had a brother, Kozmin."
"Never mind."
"Suits me."
"'Course. She's family." He snorts.
"Why are you asking me all this stuff, anyway? It's got nothing to do with you."
"We have tough times ahead. I need you at your best."
"Your relationship with your sister seems to really bother you. I want to help."
"Call it curiosity."

"Just spectating others' fuck-ups, huh? That fun to you?"

His hands clench and unclench at his sides.
"Sorry, that was out of line. Just don't know what you're getting out of all this. Don't know what you want."

"Magran's tits, I'm not your fuckin' project!"

His hands clench and unclench at his sides.
"Yeah, sure. Can't have a dull blade in your belt, huh?"
"This isn't a problem you can solve. It's up to me and her to work out."

"...If I ever see her again."

He deflates, his shoulder slumping forward, the anger that had inspired his lecture gone.
"I understand."
"Then stop complaining about it."
"Do you know were she is?"
"Hold on. Do you have a thing for Fassina?"
"Sure, who wouldn't?"
"Hey, maybe you want to, uh, put in a good word for me?"
"Since when am I the party matchmaker?"
"Somehow I don't think that'd work with her. Call it a hunch."
"I'll see what I can do."
"Yeah... yeah. She does seem like one to make up her own mind, huh? She's smart like that."
"I know it's probably a lost cause, but she's just so smart."
"Come on, you're a natural." He elbows you in the ribs with a chuckle.
"Said she was going to Neketaka. Went looking for her, but I didn't find a thing."
"After a couple months at the Mare I get a letter from her, just wanting to let me know she was alive."

"It didn't say anything else, though. And she won't write me back, no matter how many letters I send.

"Guess she's still sore."
"I don't like being back here, but I think maybe- maybe we make a good showing in the fights, I get the money, and I make things right."
"See, there's a certain glory that comes with being a champion of Kazuwari, and with glory comes money."
"You're not wrong - I'm not much of a leader. The voice tricks people. They hear power in it, want to follow."
"Has the journey been everything you thought it'd be?"
"Before I met you, I'd never even heard of Ukaizo. Now I'm standing on it, 'bout to meet a god. So, nah. Never expected any of this." He laughs.
"Can't say I ever had my life threatened by two vengeful goddesses at once, so, no. Not really."
"Did you ever have to beat someone up?"
"Sure, a few times. Mostly for vandalizing the shrine with lewd pictures."
"Anyway, we did have this one Waelite who'd come back every couple weeks for a new beating. Still don't quite know why. I didn't participate, mind you."
"Not that I've got anything against Eothasians."
He casts a quick glance in Edér's direction.
He casts a quick glance in Edér's and Xoti's direction.
He casts a quick glance in Xoti's direction.
"Don't count yourself out. Who knows what'll happen?"
"Good luck. I suspect you're going to need it."
"She's too good for you."
"I'll play it cool. I can do that."
"Appreciate the confidence boost, Watcher. Thanks."
"Appreciate the confidence boost, Watcher. Thanks."
"I am content to stay out of crew politics, but I heard my name in the midst of your pointless muttering." Fassina narrows her eyes and studies both of you.
"Nothing! Nothing at all!" Konstanten cuts a glare in your direction, daring you to say anything.

"Belfetto. And now I have my answer. You will excuse me." 

She spins on her heel and looks away, but you catch the ghost of a smile fighting its way up from under her scowl.
"Xoti and Maia are together at least in part 'cause of you."
"I just want a bit of that Watcher magic is all." He grins.
"You're right. I'm sorry for intruding."
He grunts. "Thanks for asking, though. I mean it."
"I'll do what I can to win."
"I don't plan on dying, so you might be seeing her sooner than you think."
[Say nothing.]
[Nod.]
"Shit, I'd hope so. Don't think the alternative'd be much fun."
"Sure. Got it. You won't hear about it again."
"Hey, Watcher, I see what you're doing. Helping me work through this thing with my sister."
"Talking about it won't fix things, but... it helps."
"Wanted you to know that."
He claps you lightly on the shoulder and smiles, his eyes shining with genuine warmth.
"Hey there, Watcher."
"Looks like something's eatin' you."
He smiles at your approach and motions for you to join him.
"You gettin' enough sleep? You look like you could use a break."
"But you were asking about my crew."
"There's something about her that gets me all twisted up."
"Beautiful, too, but that goes without sayin'."
"Damn."
"His hives weren't doing good to start, so when the bad weather came, there weren't enough bees to keep them all warm."
Ydwin's gaze flickers over Konstanten. She rolls her eyes and shakes her head.
"We ain't the ones go around blowing up bridges and shooting off rifles every which way now, are we?" Hands on her hips, Xoti huffs.
"He'd laugh the entire time. Creepy as shit."
"Me for one. Lass be four pounds of anger in a quarter-pound bag."
"Damn."
"Didn't expect to be travelling with someone like Fassina, I can tell you that much."
"Then there were Perso and Claria, twins from Old Vailia. Probably carried a library's worth of grimoires between them."
"Then there were Perso and Claria, twins from Old Vailia. Probably carried a library's worth of grimoires between them."
"The tattoos look good on you."
"You got a way with compliments, Watcher. Keep 'em coming." He winks.

"Heh, thanks. Can't say I pay much attention to the latest trends - not too fond of the Vailian passion for puffy sleeves, for one thing - but I still make an effort to look sharp.

"For the ladies." He winks.
"Well hey, thanks." He grins and claps you on the shoulder.
Ydwin's gaze flickers over Konstanten. She rolls her eyes and shakes her head.
"Anyway. Enough about that."

"Her grimace and your smile... the pairing is so insane that it just might be brilliant. Wish I'd thought of it first." 

She gives Konstanten's shoulder an encouraging squeeze.
"Anything I should know about, captain? Konstanten?" She swivels her full attention onto him, dissecting him with her gaze.
"Then this has nothing to do with the scented candle someone left next to my reading pile? Does it, dwarf?"
"Uh, heh. What do you want me to say? No?"
"So... you and Fassina. Any progress there?"
"Hel, Watcher, I don't know. Pretty sure the only thing she's got eyes for is the gilded pages of Aloth's fancy grimoire."
"Is wasting time all that you two can accomplish together?" Incredulous, Fassina snaps her book shut and looks from you to Konstanten.
"There's a lot you could learn that you won't find in any of those books, Fassina. Well, most of them."
"On second thought, leave me out of this."
"I wish you had left me out of it the moment the topic was broached! You are my captain. Act like it."
"I serve on your crew. I am not here to have my heart dissected for study." Fassina seems ready to say more, but instead she recovers her composure, pulling a lock of hair behind her ear.
"...Guess that's that, then. Thanks for the 'help', friend."

"I do not need you or anyone to convince me that Konstanten is a good man, handsome, even talented. I just want..." 

Cutting off her speech with a gasp, Fassina's gaze slowly turns toward him.

"Sure, sure." Konstanten chuckles softly to himself.

He hurries to help Fassina pick up her dropped books, a broad smile plastered across his face.
"I swear, you are like the worms clinging to our ship's hull."

"Might be I can even teach you a few chants you don't know."

Fassina sputters something incoherent while Konstanten laughs. They continue their tête-à-tête with lowered voices just outside your hearing.
"You two may explore one another to your heart's content." She banishes you with a halfhearted wave.
"Aren't you just becoming everything you hated about Arkemyr?"

"Postenago, I said nothing! Go tend to your damned scented candles and leave me be! Tonderie, what a waste of breath!" 

Fassina gathers up her books, quills, and other supplies - dropping half of them in the process.
"Handsome and talented? Did I hear you right?"
"Cuè, are you going to tell me that I am a loveless creature who keeps anyone of substance at a distance?"
"Next you will say that I prefer the company of simpletons and imps because it makes me feel superior. Again, none of this is new."
"Hel, Watcher, I don't know. Pretty sure the only thing catchin' her eye is her newest grimoire."

"Watcher, hey."

Konstanten raises his hand in greeting, but it's clear his attention isn't entirely on you.
"Maybe it's that attitude, or the way she hurls those spells like they're spears aimed right at her old boss's head."
"She's really something."
"Thanks for bringing me along, Watcher."
"Real glad Eothas was there to give us a hand." He chuckles at his own joke.
"Then there's aunt Korina, my ma's sister, uncle Albret, cousins Alin and Narsiza."

"No messy emotions mucking up your glory tour around the archipelago."

His hands clench and unclench at his sides.
With a twitch of a furry blue ear, Serafen lets out a low growl. He doesn't look your direction, though.
"If I am to have any hope of achievement in this life, I must catch up on reading."
"Bertenno gave me that same speech a dozen, a hundred times."

"But... if you can stop yourself from pestering me for even a single hour, there is a space by my bunk. You can lurk there and help me study." 

Flustered, she snatches one of the books from his hands.
"Like what?"
"Who could drink the most beer before peeing themselves. Who could bed the most village folk. That kind of thing."
"Oh, and baby Petru - was a boy last time I saw him, must be a grown man by now."
"See, his real talent lies in brewing. Mead, mostly, but beer, too. Keeps him happy and a roof over his head."
"I don't know how to tell you this, Konstanten, but..."
"You look perfectly alive to me."
[Stare at him meaningfully.]
"Ah Hel, you're not serious, are you?"
"I'm kidding. You're very alive."
[Stare at him meaningfully.]
"Gods beyond." His eyes widen and take on a distant look.
"You're pullin' my leg." He looks unsure for a moment, then breaks into a wide grin and a deep chuckle.
"Almost had me there." He snorts. "Anyway..."
He dismisses your look with a laugh and a wave of his hand.
"Phew. Had me worried for a second there!" He exhales a theatrical sigh of relief.

"Thought- thought I'd be sleeping on a beach in the afterlife, not doing the same old shit I always was."

He turns wide eyes on you. Then he starts to laugh.
"Thinkin' you had me there, didn't you? Heh." He wipes a tear of laughter from the corner of his eye and claps you on the shoulder.

"You're a weird one. Must be why I like you.

"Anyway, back to business, eh?"
He stares into the middle distance, brows drawn, exuding a certain restlessness that's unlike the laid-back man you've grown used to traveling with.
"What's bothering you?"
[Leave him to his thoughts.]
As you turn to go, you hear him heave a large, sigh, but he says nothing more.
"That obvious, huh?" He chews a large knuckle, considering his next words.
"You secretly a cipher or something?"
"You look about ready to run."
"Thinking about your family?"
[Shrug.]
"Thing is, I didn't think we'd make it. First through the Crucible, then out through the other side of the Beyond."
"Something like that." He shifts his weight from foot to foot. A deep frown cuts furrows across his face.
"Damned ciphers. Not even the inside of a man's head's sacred to you."
"I don't need to read your mind to see that you're wrestling with something."
"But here we are, in spite of gods and a godsdamned giant crocodile. Living."
"Guess I can't fault you for trusting the evidence of your eyes."
"You wanted to die?"
[Motion for him to go on.]
"No, no, don't take it the wrong way. Didn't mean that."
"Just didn't think about what would come after. What I'd need to do."
"Make good on your promise, you mean?"
"Eat crow, more like. Go home."
"I told Roza we'd be better off cutting our losses, leaving Kazuwari while we still had our lives."
"Then I came back here without her and won the damn thing. With your help, obviously." He rushes to add the last sentence.
"Now I've got some fame and a little bit of coin to show for it. Enough coin to set my pa up right. Just like she said I would."

"And when I find her, I'll have to tell her this whole spectacle was worth it after all, only she gets none of the glory.

"None of the glory... and none of pa's thanks."

"Things aren't right between them, never really have been.

"I think she believed that doin' this for him would've helped."
"But that's not my problem, and it sure as Hel isn't yours." He shakes his and waves the worry for his sister away.
[Continue listening.]
[Interrupt him.] "I've heard enough."
"Good. I'm tired of talkin'." He rubs a hands across his eyes.

"Just wanted to tell you... I don't know. You took a chance on an old dwarf in a brothel, and you didn't have to.

"So, thanks."
He reaches out to shake your hand, then pulls you into a quick, tight hug instead.
